Jets vs Bills.title: Bills 40, Jets 14 | Final score, stats to know + game highlights
Jets vs Bills.content: Contributing Correspondent Location: Highmark Stadium Tickets distributed: 70,728 Final score: Bills 40, Jets 14 Records: Bills (13-3), Jets (4-12) Next opponent: Bills at Patriots on TBD The Buffalo Bills clinched the No. 2 seed in the AFC with their 40-14 victory over the New York Jets. On offense, QB Josh Allen played three quarters, passing for 182 yards and two touchdowns and rushing for another. RB James Cook led the ground attack rushing for 53 yards and a touchdown. WR Tyrell Shavers led all receivers in yards with 69 and a touchdown. The defense forced three takeaways and had 4.0 total sacks. DE A.J. Epenesa, Von Miller and DT Ed Oliver each had 1.0 sack while DT DaQuan Jones and DE Greg Rousseau each had 0.5 sacks. CB Christian Benford and DT Jordan Phillips both had interceptions and LB Matt Milano had the fumble recovery. Oliver had a forced fumble as well. LB Joe Andreessen led tacklers with eight. Additional notes: After winning the opening toss and electing to receive the football first, the Buffalo Bills offense marched right down the field to score the first points of the day. On the drive, Allen completed four of six passes for 56 yards, including key third down conversions of 12 yards and 23 yards to WR Khalil Shakir and WR Mack Hollins respectively. On their first redzone play, Allen threw a short pass to TE Dalton Kincaid, who picked up 11 yards after spinning out of a tackle from CB D.J. Reed. Following a pass interference flag in the end zone Allen snuck the ball into the end zone to score the touchdown and give the Bills the early 7-0 lead. The Jets took over for their first possession of the game following the Bills touchdown. The Jets utilized their run game to move the ball down the field while QB Aaron Rodgers completed three passes for 24 yards. On fourth-and-one from the Bills 24-yard line, Rodgers handed the ball to RB Breece Hall, but he was stuffed at the line of scrimmage for no gain by DE Greg Rousseau, forcing the turnover-on-downs. On the Jets ensuing drive after the Bills punted the football, they once again were moving the ball down the field. Rodgers completed a 28-yard catch and run to WR Garrett Wilson that set up the Jets in the red zone. Two plays later though, Rodgers dropped back and threw a pass short, that was tipped at the line by Rousseau and intercepted by DT Jordan Phillips who subsequently jumped into the stands with fans. On just their third drive of the game, the Bills were forced to punt once again. P Sam Martin pinned the Jets deep in their own territory at the 5-yard line. After a false start and a rush that went for -1 yard, Rodgers dropped back to pass from his own 2-yard line. DE A.J. Epenesa beat LT Max Mitchell around the edge and found his way to Rodgers, sacking him for the safety. Both teams took turns trading punts to start the second half. On the Jets second drive of the third quarter, the Bills defense took the ball away from the Jets offense again. First Rousseau sacked Rodgers on second-and-15. Then Rodgers dropped back to pass and looked to WR Allen Lazard but instead found the hands of CB Christian Benford who ran the ball back 24 yards. The Bills were given an additional 15 yards because of an unnecessary roughness called on Rodgers who pushed Benford as he was running out of bounds. On the next drive, WR Amari Cooper got involved immediately, catching a nine yard pass before four plays later catching a 30-yard touchdown. Cooper rose up over CB Brandin Echols and hauled in the touchdown pass. The Bills piled on in the third quarter by scoring two touchdowns and forcing another takeaway. RB James Cook punched in a one-yard touchdown at the goal line to bring the score to 26-0. On the Jets first play on their next drive, Wilson caught the ball and broke away from a tackle attempt, but then DT Ed Oliver punched the ball out and LB Matt Milano landed on top of the fumble recovery. With possession at the Jets 14-yard line, Allen scrambled to his right and threw a pass across his body into the back of the endzone to WR Keon Coleman, who caught the ball over Reed and LB Quincy Williams. The Bills ended the third quarter with another sack by Oliver. To start the fourth quarter, QB Mitchell Trubisky stepped in. He and the offense picked up where Allen and the starters left off, throwing a touchdown to WR Tyrell Shavers. Shavers caught the pass from Trubisky and ran 69 yards into the endzone untouched for the first catch and first touchdown of his career. The Jets avoided a shutout when QB Tyrod Taylor checked into the game in the fourth quarter. Taylor led the Jets on a 13-play, 75-yard drive to score the Jets first touchdown of the game that ended in a Wilson touchdown grab. They then completed the two point conversion to TE Tyler Conklin to make the score 40-8. On their next drive, Taylor threw a 20-yard touchdown pass to Conklin, but threw an incompletion on the two-point conversion attempt, bringing the score to 40-14. Lineup Notes: CB Rasul Douglas returned to the lineup after missing two games with a knee injury; S Taylor Rapp returned to the lineup after missing two games with a neck injury; LB Matt Milano returned to the lineup after missing one game with a biceps/groin injury; WR Tyrell Shavers was elevated to the game day roster; DT Austin Johnson and CB Kaiir Elam were inactive. Key Stats and Facts: Scoring Plays: 08:14 1Q | BUF 7 NYJ 0 | Josh Allen left guard for 1 yard, TOUCHDOWN. 02:34 2Q | BUF 9 NYJ 0 | Aaron Rodgers sacked in End Zone for -2 yards, SAFETY (A.J. Epenesa). 00:02 2Q | BUF 12 NYJ 0 | Tyler Bass 39-yard field goal is GOOD. 5:19 3Q | BUF 19 NYJ 0 | Josh Allen pass deep right to Amari Cooper for 30 yards, TOUCHDOWN. 1:17 3Q | BUF 26 NYJ 0 | James Cook left guard for 1 yard, TOUCHDOWN. 00:21 3Q | BUF 33 NYJ 0 | Josh Allen pass short left to Keon Coleman for 14 yards, TOUCHDOWN. 12:48 4Q | BUF 40 NYJ 0 | Mitchell Trubisky pass short left to Tyrell Shavers for 69 yards, TOUCHDOWN. 7:03 4Q | BUF 40 NYJ 8 | Tyrod Taylor pass short right to Garrett Wilson for 9 yards, TOUCHDOWN. TWO-POINT CONVERSION ATTEMPT. Tyrod Taylor pass to Tyler Conklin is complete. ATTEMPT SUCCEEDS. 2:00 4Q | BUF 40 NYJ 14 | Tyrod Taylor pass deep right to Tyler Conklin for 20 yards, TOUCHDOWN. Bills have won their 10th consecutive home game in a three-point win over the Patriots. The Bills won their 11th game of the season in the motor city. The Rams snapped the Bills' seven-game win streak on a historic day from Josh Allen. Bills clinched the AFC East title with their seventh consecutive win. It was a magic night in snowy Orchard Park. Bills win sixth straight game and hand Kansas City its first loss of the season Bills have won their fifth consecutive game and first game in Indianapolis since 1998. The Bills won their sixth consecutive game against Miami in dramatic fashion. The Bills won their first game in Seattle since November 2004. Buffalo gets its fifth win of the season in Week 7. Bills snap a two-game losing streak with a road win in New York. The Bills fall to 3-2 after a last-second 59-yard game-winning field goal by Houston. © 2024 The Buffalo Bills. All rights reserved

Jets vs Bills.title: New York Jets vs. Buffalo Bills Live Score and Stats - December 29, 2024 Gametracker - CBSSports.com
Jets vs Bills.content: If not listed, please contact your TV provider. ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. (AP) Josh Allen reflected on Buffalo’s many offseason critics and doubters when asked about the Bills achieving their latest milestones while sewing up the AFC’s No. 2 seed with a 40-14 rout of the unraveling and undisciplined New York Jets on Sunday. It was a the Bills quarterback’s “I told you so moment,” even though Allen elected not to use those exact words. “It speaks to the staff that we’ve got here, the guys that we’ve got in this locker room, how this team is put together and the culture that we have,” Allen said. “We didn’t really pay attention to the preseason notions, but we heard them and we saw them and we knew what people were saying. "But it had no effect on us.” Well, that might be a stretch when it comes to motivation. What’s unquestioned is how Allen and the Bills (13-3) overcame a young, patchwork roster following the offseason departure of six of eight team captains - including Stefon Diggs being traded to Houston - to run away with their fifth consecutive AFC East title and win a franchise-best 13 games for the fifth time in team history, and third since 2020. Coach Sean McDermott didn’t leave much doubt as to who deserves the most credit for leading the Bills to their sixth consecutive playoff berth, and helping them set the single-season franchise records for points (509) and touchdowns (63). “I think Josh Allen continues to show why he should be the MVP,” McDermott said. “I’ve been around this league long enough to know to see MVP every year for many years. And what he has done on this team and this organization in this community - and no offense to anybody else - but I’ve got a hard time believing that someone’s done more.” Allen threw two touchdown passes and ran for another score to become the NFL’s first player to score 40 touchdowns in five consecutive seasons. He did so in an outing Buffalo blew the game open by capitalizing on two Jets turnovers and scoring three touchdowns over a 5:01 span in the closing minutes of the third quarter. Buffalo’s defense forced three takeaways overall and sacked Aaron Rodgers four times, including a 2-yard loss for a safety in the second quarter. Nothing went right in what became a comedy of errors for Rodgers and the Jets (4-12). New York will finish with five or fewer wins for the seventh time over a 14-season playoff drought - the NFL’s longest active streak. “It’s kind of like the season, it just got away from us. Too many games got away from us,” said Rodgers, who finished 12 of 18 for 112 yards and two interceptions before being pulled in favor of Tyrod Taylor with Buffalo leading 40-0. “We were moving the ball well and then just hit a wall. And that’s kind of been the season.” Rodgers, who entered the game with 499 career TD passes and looking to become just the fifth player to reach 500, was instead shut out and became the NFL’s most sacked quarterback. The 41-year-old has now been sacked 568 times, moving ahead of Tom Brady (565) and into first place on the career list. Taylor accounted for all of New York’s points, with a 9-yard touchdown pass to Garrett Wilson and a 20-yarder to Tyler Conklin. Discipline was an issue for a Jets team that fell to 2-9 since Jeff Ulbrich took over as interim coach. New York finished with 16 accepted penalties for 120 yards. “It’s frustrating, it’s embarrassing, it’s maddening. It’s all of that,” Ulbrich said. Allen had a short and efficient outing, finishing 16 of 27 for 182 yards with a 30-yard TD pass to Amari Cooper and a 14-yarder to Keon Coleman before giving way to backup Mitchell Trubisky with Buffalo leading 33-0 through three quarters. And Trubisky piled on by completing a 69-yard touchdown pass to practice squad call-up Tyrell Shavers 2:23 into the fourth quarter. Shavers became the 13th Bills player to catch a touchdown pass, matching the single-season NFL record, to validate the “everybody eats” mantra Allen and the offense used to approach this season. The Bills defense enjoyed a dominating performance to snap a shaky three-game stretch in which it combined to allow 1,357 yards, 86 first downs and 107 points. “I wouldn’t say need ... and I don’t want to say reassurance, either,” said A.J. Epenesa, who sacked Rodgers for the safety. “But it just shows that this is what we can do and this is the standard that needs to be upheld.” Allen’s 1-yard score was the 65th rushing TD of his career, matching the team record held by Thurman Thomas. ... James Cook scored on a 4-yard run for his 15th TD rushing of the season, one short of the Bills' single-season record set by O.J. Simpson in a 14-game season in 1975. Cook matched Allen, who scored 15 last year. ... Wilson reached 1,000 yards receiving for the third straight year to start his career, the first Jets player to do so and the 10th player in NFL history to accomplish the feat. Jets: Close the season by hosting the Miami Dolphins. Bills: Play their regular-season finale at the New England Patriots. --- AP NFL: https://apnews.com/hub/nfl Copyright 2024 STATS LLC and Associated Press. Jets vs Bills.title: Week 17 New York Jets vs. Buffalo Bills Box score, stats and summary feat. Josh Allen
Jets vs Bills.content: The Buffalo Bills and the New York Jets met in Week 17 of the NFL season, in a game with almost no meaning for playoff concerns. The Jets entered the game with a 4-11 record, having been eliminated many weeks before, while the Bills had all but locked the second seed in the AFC. As expected, there wasn't much competitiveness in the game. Buffalo jumped to a two-possession lead at halftime, including a bizarre safety from quarterback Aaron Rodgers. The Jets scored no points in the first half. In the second half, it never looked like the visitors would be able to recover at any point. After a slow start to the third quarter, Buffalo took flight and scored 28 straight points, with the blowout reaching 40-0. At least the Jets had two touchdowns to take some of the embarrassment away. Looking to predict NFL playoff Scenarios? Try our NFL Playoff Predictor for real-time simulations and stay ahead of the game! The veteran quarterback had yet another bad performance, missing open receivers constantly while throwing multiple picks. He was pulled from the game late, when Buffalo already had a huge advantage on the score board. There aren't many things that went right for the Jets in this game, but Garrett Wilson, who could be looking for a trade according to Ian Rapoport, at least had a good performance. The offense stalled for almost the entire game. Allowing 40 points is always a bad thing, but it also comes to mind that the unity registered no sacks or interceptions throughout the game. Luckily for them, there's only one game left in the season. Allen solidified his MVP campaign with another solid performance, including a fantastic throw to Amari Cooper to score a touchdown. With one week to go, he remains the favorite to win the award in Vegas. One thing that could become a concern for Buffalo in January is their running game, with Cook amassing under 3.0 yards per carry on Sunday. Running the ball efficiently is one of the biggest keys to win playoff games. Buffalo Bills Nation! NFL Draft order.title: 2025 NFL Draft order: Patriots in driver's seat for No. 1 pick | FOX Sports
NFL Draft order.content: POPULAR SEARCHES BROWSE BY With the 2024 NFL regular season nearing the finish line, the 2025 NFL Draft order is constantly on the move. Stay up to date with where each team sits after Week 17 games: The NFL Draft will take place from Thursday, April 24, 2025, through Saturday, April 26, 2025. Here is a breakdown by round: The 2025 NFL Draft will take place in Green Bay, Wisconsin — home of the Packers. The draft will be held around Lambeau Field and Titletown campus. The selection order is dictated by the reverse order of finish in the previous season. Each round starts with the team that finished with the worst record and ends with the Super Bowl champions, unless any trades have occurred. Teams that didn't make the playoffs are given draft slots 1-20. In addition to this, up to a total of 32 compensatory picks are awarded to teams that lost significant free agents. These picks are made after the final seventh-round selection. Some of the top prospects in this year's NFL Draft are Travis Hunter, Will Johnson, Shedeur Sanders and Ashton Jeanty. For more, check out our latest 2025 NFL Mock Draft. [Want great stories delivered right to your inbox? Create or log in to your FOX Sports account, follow leagues, teams and players to receive a personalized newsletter daily.]

NFL Draft order.title: 2025 NFL Draft order: Major shakeup at the top after Giants, Raiders and Jaguars all win in Week 17 - CBSSports.com
NFL Draft order.content: If not listed, please contact your TV provider. There was some major shakeup at the top of the 2025 NFL Draft order in Week 17. The New York Giants, who controlled their own destiny to secure the No. 1 pick, put up 45 points to upset the Indianapolis Colts. And if that wasn't enough, the Jacksonville Jaguars took down the Tennessee Titans and the Las Vegas Raiders won their second straight game after winning just two of their first 14 to open the season. That's three teams with three or fewer wins securing victories in the same week -- the first time that's happened in Week 17 or later since 2005, according to CBS Sports research. Those results produced the following: The New England Patriots now hold the top spot, followed by the Titans, Giants, Browns and Jaguars. Of those teams, Cleveland is the only one still left to play. It is currently taking on the Miami Dolphins. With Week 17 nearly complete, CBSSports.com looks at where teams would be picking at this moment in time. Also listed is each club's pending free agents and potential needs based on those players who may be leaving. The draft order, via Tankathon.com, is ordered by win-loss record and ties are broken by strength of schedule. Team needs are a combination of current needs and looking ahead to pending free agents. Notable pending free agents are listed rather than the full list. NFL Draft order.title: 2025 NFL Draft order: Where Pats stand in first round after Week 17 loss - Yahoo Sports
NFL Draft order.content: 2025 NFL Draft order: Where Pats stand in first round after Week 17 loss originally appeared on NBC Sports Boston The No. 1 pick in the 2025 NFL Draft is very much in play for the New England Patriots. Saturday's 40-7 loss to the Los Angeles Chargers brought the Patriots' 2024 record to 3-13. They owned the No. 2 pick heading into Sunday's slate of games, but vaulted up to No. 1 after the New York Giants beat the Indianapolis Colts to improve to 3-13. The Jacksonville Jaguars and Las Vegas Raiders both moved to 4-12 with wins Sunday, meaning there are only four three-win teams -- the Patriots, Tennessee Titans, Giants and Cleveland Browns, who are each 3-13 after losing in Week 17. The Patriots own the strength of schedule tiebreaker over all three of those teams thanks to a weaker strength of schedule. Here's the updated order for the top 10 picks in the first round of the 2025 NFL Draft. This chart will be updated throughout Week 17: !function(){"use strict";window.addEventListener("message",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data["datawrapper-height"]){var e=document.querySelectorAll("iframe");for(var t in a.data["datawrapper-height"])for(var r=0;r<e.length;r++)if(e[r].contentWindow===a.source){var i=a.data["datawrapper-height"][t]+"px";e[r].style.height=i}}}))}(); The Patriots wrap up their 2024 campaign next Sunday at home against the Buffalo Bills. Another loss would guarantee them the No. 1 pick, while a win would drop them to no lower than fourth.

Leicester City vs Man City.title: Man City 2-0 Leicester (Dec 29, 2024) Game Analysis - ESPN
Leicester City vs Man City.content: Janusz Michallik believes that Manchester City will still play their part in deciding who wins the Premier League title. Manchester City won for the first time in five Premier League games on Sunday after goals from Erling Haaland and Savinho earned a 2-0 victory at Leicester City in manager Pep Guardiola's 500th game in charge. The champions' second win in 14 games across all competitions meant they climbed two spots to fifth place with 31 points, 11 behind leaders Liverpool who have two games in hand. Leicester remain in the relegation zone in 18th. "We needed it, all of us," Guardiola told Sky Sports. "Just relief, that is the word to express how all of us feel. We have done incredible things and now we struggle to win games so now it's just relief." Savinho netted his first goal for City in the 21st minute when he pounced on a rebound from Phil Foden's long shot after Leicester goalkeeper Jakub Stolarczyk pushed the ball into his path. The Brazilian fired into the roof of the net from a tight angle. Haaland, who has two goals in eight league games in the worst stretch of his Premier League career, doubled City's lead in the 74th minute when he headed home a looping cross from Savinho, who latched onto a pass from Kevin de Bruyne. "Things happen and we have to keep going, we have to stay positive and focus on the right things," Haaland said, before pushing Guardiola in the direction of the visiting fans who were chanting his name. "It's always a relief to score and that was an important goal to go 2-0 up." The victory was far from a walkover, however. Leicester fans screamed for a penalty early on when Jamie Vardy found himself one-on-one with goalkeeper Stefan Ortega from a counter-attack. Ortega brought Vardy down in the box but Man City were saved by the offside flag. Josko Gvardiol nearly cost Guardiola's team a first-half goal with a disastrous header back to Ortega that was intercepted. City's disorganised back line saw Facundo Buonanotte clatter a shot off the bar minutes later. Leicester had another glorious chance early in the second half when Vardy headed into the box and James Justin got a touch on it that looked heading for the back of the net before Manuel Akanji cleared it off the line. Vardy missed an absolute sitter when he launched a shot just over the bar from close range. "It was tight in the second half, they were much better. We don't have energy to sustain 90 minutes. Hopefully the New Year can help us bounce back," Guardiola said. "To get results you have to do something. To do it in the position we have, many good things happened today. It is not enjoyable right now, it is just relief. We have done incredible things for many years. It is not the best." Leicester manager Ruud van Nistelrooy, who shared a long hug with Guardiola after the final whistle, told the BBC he has to judge his team's performance as well as the result. "I wouldn't do the players credit if I didn't. We're professional, we know it's about results but we have to look through that because of the performance today," he said. "We have to be judged on results and translate performances into results."

TV DAZN Best Streaming Services Best VPN Services SiriusXM Tickets Stadium Guides Soccer NFL NBA MLB NCAAF Dom Farrell KING POWER STADIUM, LEICESTER — Manchester City halted a five-match winless run with a battling and often fortuitous 2-0 triumph at Leicester City. The frailties that meant Pep Guardiola's reigning Premier League champions headed into this match on a dismal trot of one win in 13 across all competitions were again on display, most notably as Leicester repeatedly cut through a flimsy press and vacant midfield, during the first half. But the lack of cutting edge that has similarly afflicted City over the past couple of months was not a problem in the East Midlands. Savinho scored a long-awaited first goal for the club since his summer move from Troyes in the 21st minute. It was even more of a slog in the second half for English football's dominant force of recent years, who were in the rare position of being restricted to 33% of possession in the period between the restart, and Erling Haaland headed home his 14th goal of the season from Savinho's cross to seal the points. Latest live updates | Team news and lineups | Where to watch where you are Venue: King Power Stadium, LeicesterReferee: Michael Oliver Keep track of every game and every goal via SN's live Premier League scoreboard Lineups: Leicester (4-2-3-1, right to left): 41. Jakub Stolarczyk (GK) — 2. James Justin (17. Haza Choudhury), 4. Conor Coady (5. Caleb Okoli), 23. Jannik Vestergaard, 16. Victor Kristiansen — 8. Harry Winks (20. Patson Daka), 24. Boubakary Soumare — 11. Bilal El Khannouss, 40. Facundo Buonanotte, 10. Stephy Mavididi (37. Will Alves) — 9. Jamie Vardy Man City (4-1-4-1, right to left): 18. Stefan Ortega (GK) — 82. Rico Lewis, 25. Manuel Akanji, 6. Nathan Ake (2. Kyle Walker), 24. Josko Gvardiol — 8. Mateo Kovacic — 47. Phil Foden (87. James McAtee), 17. Kevin De Bruyne, 20. Bernardo Silva, 26. Savinho — 9. Erling Haaland MORE: All the latest Man City news | Premier League schedule for 2024/25 | Latest Premier League top scorer rankings City started with a flicker of their old swagger as Haaland forced Jakub Stolarczyk into a sharp save from Kevin De Bruyne's volleyed cross. But a 10th-minute incident seemed to drain City's heavily diluted self-belief. Jamie Vardy sprung into the box and was brought down by Stefan Ortega. An offside flag meant an obvious penalty concession was averted as Guardiola's men struggled to recover their poise. As such, the breakthrough came against the run of play, Phil Foden moved smartly to get off a snap shot from Rico Lewis' pass. Stolarczyk saved, but could only push the ball out to the on-rushing Savinho, who clattered home a high finish from a tight angle. Available in the US Savinho nets his first goal for Manchester City to give them a crucial lead in Leicester. 👏📺 Peacock | #LEIMCI pic.twitter.com/kzwt8NufxE Available in the UK Savinho pounces and Man City lead! 💥 pic.twitter.com/k8pQmq3WkC Leicester grew into the contest, and caused increasing panic in a visiting defence, that was manfully marshalled by Nathan Ake. In contrast to the ice-cool Dutchman, Josko Gvardiol was shockingly accident-prone as half-time approached and his botched aerial clearance led to Facundo Buonanotte heading against the post. City were late out for the second period, but Guardiola's words of wisdom did little to stem the tide. Manuel Akanji cleared off the line to deny James Justin before Vardy wasted a glorious close-range opportunity. The veteran striker would rue that profligacy in the final 20 minutes as Guardiola's side finally strung together a second-half attack with conviction. The criminally under-used England U21 playmaker James McAtee, on for Foden, started it with some wonderfully smart play on the right. De Bruyne worked the ball to Savinho, who crossed for Haaland to thump in a header at the back post. A much-needed 14th Premier League goal of the season for the big Norwegian and a much-needed three points for City. But perhaps it's McAtee, brimming with confidence, and Savinho after a breakthrough afternoon who can give them a route out of the darkness. Available in the US ERLING HAALAND IS BACK IN THE GOALS. 💪Man City make it 2-0 against Leicester!📺 Peacock | #LEIMCI pic.twitter.com/ZxNZNzRGp6 Available in the UK "The smile is back!" 😁Erling Haaland makes it 2-0 to Manchester City! pic.twitter.com/RgWPjiw0mO That's it, Manchester City win for the first time in six matches and the second time in 14. Don't expect this to spark one of their patented monster runs. They were pretty awful for large chunks of this game against a Leicester side who, if they avoid relegation, will not do so by very much. Guardiola is in deep conversation with Harry Winks, briefly stroking his face. He's a strange man, all told, but he can enjoy a nice glass of wine tonight. Maybe you will too. Thanks for joining us. 90 mins+5: Leicester keep coming and Patson Daka heads over under pressure from Lewis. It's a corner. Guardiola and Van Nistelrooy are already having a cuddle and a chat on the sidelines. 90 mins: Will Alves replaces Mavididi for Leicester. He'll have five minutes of added time to strut his stuff. 89 mins: That's a clever header from Vardy that glances the top of Ortega's crossbar. If he'd done as well with easier opportunities today the outcome would probably look quite different. 87 mins: Boyhood City fan McAtee is revelling in this cameo in front of an adoring away support. Haaland drives a break and finds the England U21 star, who curls for the top corner from outside the box. It wasn't far away. 81 mins: Buy a ticket, lads! Choudhury, who is on to provide a little extra thrust down the right, fires a fine ball across the Manchester City goalmouth but there's no one there to finish. 74 mins: GOOOOOOAAAAAAALLLLLLL!!!!!!! Erling Haaland!!!!!! Smash, meet grab. Finally City string together a nice break, with McAtee the instigator. Play moves to Savinho via De Bruyne and the Brazilian hangs up a delicious cross to the far post for Haaland to head home. The City fans away to my left go potty... then sing McAtee's name. Available in the US ERLING HAALAND IS BACK IN THE GOALS. 💪Man City make it 2-0 against Leicester!📺 Peacock | #LEIMCI pic.twitter.com/ZxNZNzRGp6 Available in the UK "The smile is back!" 😁Erling Haaland makes it 2-0 to Manchester City! pic.twitter.com/RgWPjiw0mO 69 mins: Ake, only recently back from injury for City, is coming off and Kyle Walker will enter the fray. Hamza Choudhury replaces Justin for Leicester. Which might mean a change of shape. Doesn't look like it just yet. 68 mins: Oh Jamie Vardy, what have you done? Mavididi finds the Leicester captain in the middle of the six yard box. He volleys over and slaps the crossbar in frustration. 65 mins: In a move some fans have been calling for all season, James McAtee is coming on for Manchester City. Meanwhile, Vardy arrows a poor cross over everyone from a good position the right channel. El Khannouss flies into Lewis in over-enthusiastic fashion and the visitors can make their change. Foden, who looks exhausted, makes way. 62 mins: Kristiansen gets forward from full-back, Ajkanji with an important near-post header. Now Lewis fouls the Leicester man and it's a free-kick in a good position. It gets to Vestergaard at the back post, Vardy tries to turn goalwards, James does, Akanji off the line! 59 mins: Now a dangerous free-kick for Leicester, floated to the back post and Haaland is there to clatter away. All hands to the pump for Manchester City. 57 mins: Soumare gives away a pretty needless free-kick on the left. De Bruyne over it but Foden delivers and does so beautifully. Soumare atones by clearing behind. Haaland pops a volley towards goal from the latest short corner routine but Stolarczyk plunges onto it. 55 mins: Crucial clearance behind from Vestergaard. Foden crosses to the back post, Silva nods across and Gvardiol was lurking for the sucker punch, De Bruyne wastes the short corner. 54 mins: El Khannouss lets fly from range. Close enough but not worrying Ortega. The general flow of what's unfolding in front of the Manchester City goalkeeper might be though. 51 mins: Buonanotte goes down under an Ake challenge after being played through by Vardy. This will be checked. Ake is furious. No penalty. And you have to ask, if it's no penalty why isn't it a yellow for diving? City haven't really started at all this half and are inviting those sorts of situations. 48 mins: Kovacic fouls Buonanotte on halfway. He's been the lone combative participant in that City midfield at times but must be closing in on a booking. Back underway. Leicester have been out there waiting for their opponents for a little while, in fairness. And it's not warm. Manchester City get through to halftime. Again they look so vulnerable, their midfield an abomination out of possession. But Savinho's first goal for the club is the difference for now. During their ongoing slump, they also led against Sporting CP, Brighton, Feyenoord, 44 mins: This one is much better but Ake gets up brilliantly at the far post to clear. 43 mins: Corner to Leicester. They're really putting Guardiola's men under the pump. Dreadful delivery from El Khannouss but De Bruyne volleys behind to give him another go. 39 mins: BUONANOTTE AGAINST THE POST! Another perplexing decision from Gvardiol, who gets up at the back post and heads the ball up towards his own penalty spot. Via Mavididi it looks to Buonanotte, who turns a header against Orteta's right upright. Haaland and Foden then launch a blistering City break but can't find the finishing touch. 37 mins: Vardy, surely offside, finds Buonanotte. Great save from Ortega. Now the flag goes up up but the German keeper was not to know. 36 mins: Almost a bundling solo goal from Haaland! Gvardiol gets himself into some strife but Kovacic wins the second ball and City have fashioned a counter-attack. Haaland powers on past a couple of challenges, switches onto his left foot inside the box but drags just wide. 33 mins: Ohhhh, Leciester should be level! An absolute doozy of a ball in from the right by El Khannouss. Vardy leaves it, Buonanotte can't get on the end of it and it goes out for a goal kick. A wonderful cross that deserved a goal. 30 mins: De Bruyne down under a Vestergaard challenge. Some City players appeal for a penalty but the Belgian himself was rightly not especially interested. 28 mins: Haaland flexes the neck muscles on the end of a deflected Silva cross but it's easy enough for Stolarczyk to gather. 27 mins: Some swagger returning to City now, but we've seen already seen how fragile that can be. Time for Leicester to bed in. De Bruyne making a complete nonsense of a short corner helps their cause. 21 mins: GOOOOOAAAAAALLLLLLLL!!!!!!! Savinho!!!! Slightly against the run of play but how they needed that. Foden crafts something from nothing on the end of a Lewis pass and gets a shot away quickly from 25 yards. Stolarczyk parries but the onrushing Savinho cracks into the top corner on the rebound for his first City goal. Available in the US Savinho nets his first goal for Manchester City to give them a crucial lead in Leicester. 👏📺 Peacock | #LEIMCI pic.twitter.com/kzwt8NufxE Available in the UK Savinho pounces and Man City lead! 💥 pic.twitter.com/k8pQmq3WkC 19 mins: A haphazard backwards header from Gvardiol under pressure from James lets Vardy in. Ortega saves smartly and it's a corner. After a decent start, self-belief once again looks to have drained from the champions. Leicester waste the corner but Guardiola looks understandably concerned. 16 mins: More encouragement for Leicester as Vardy nips into the box. Lewis nips in smartly before the flag goes up again. City living dangerously because Vardy will time one of those before long. 12 mins: De Bruyne over the City free-kick. He scored from a similar range to this on this ground a couple of years ago... into the wall. 10 mins: Leicester scythe through the City midfield like everyone does nowadays, Ortega hesitates and brings Vardy down... offside. Good job for the City goalkeeper that it was because that was a definite penalty otherwise. 9 mins: Leicester look to break up the other end but Gvardiol closes the door on James. 7 mins: Fantastic save by Stolarczyk! Lewis floats a ball over the Leicester defence, De Bruyne volleys a first-time cross from near the byline. Haaland is on the end of it right-footed but the Foxes' keep does superbly to keep the strike out with his boot. 6 mins: Leicester's first foray ends with Mavididi sashaying into the box from the left and shooting wide of the far post. 5 mins: Kovacic coughs up possession carelessly but he and Lewis snap in to win it back before De Bruyne lashes over a left-footed sighter from way downtown. 2 mins: City with some patient, tentative possession before Savinho shifts gears past a few challenges into the box. He runs out of pitch before he can get a cross off, though. De Bruyne gets us underway. Foden starting wide right for the visitors. 4 mins before kickoff: Here come the teams, soundtracked by a bugle player. He'll probably get himself a Kasabian b-side at some point. Some flames pumped into the sky too. Appreciated the heat from that in a slightly nippy press box. 7 mins before kickoff: City are in the tunnel waiting for the hosts as the familiar strains of 'Club Foot' by Kasabian pump around the King Power. Jack Grealish, back on the bench today, appears to be in charge of morale as he aimings to lighten the mood with Erling Haaland and Kevin De Bruyne. 25 mins before kickoff: The teams are well underway with their warmups. One of the cameras servicing the stadium feed was trained on Erling Haaland for some time. As you'd expect, given the Norwegian superstar has only three goals in his past 13 Premier League games, an unheard of return for most of his career. Haaland and Phil Foden were passing the ball intently between themselves for a decent period. Guardiola needs overdue big performances from those two today. 45 mins before kickoff: De Bruyne has enjoyed himself a few times on this ground before. In the previous edition of this fixture two seasons ago, the Belgian maestro scored the only goal with this sumptuous free-kick. A pinpoint KDB free-kick at Leicester 🎯 pic.twitter.com/nMWtFBi2nX 1 hr 10 mins before kickoff: Here's the Leicester team. Vardy has indeed made it. Facundo Buonanotte will support the veteran Englishman in attack as he comes in for the suspended Jordan Ayew. Your last XI of 2024 📋#LEIMCI pic.twitter.com/efV9UQfBLi 1 hr 15 mins before kickoff: The teams are in and Kevin De Bruyne makes his first start since City's Manchester derby defeat a fortnight ago. De Bruyne replacing his compatriot Jeremy Doku is the only change to the City XI that drew 1-1 with Everton three days ago, which probably means either Phil Foden or Bernardo Silva being deployed on the right wing. Your City squad! 🩵XI | Ortega Moreno, Lewis, Akanji, Ake, Gvardiol, Kovacic, De Bruyne (C), Bernardo, Savinho, Foden, HaalandSUBS | Carson, Walker, Grealish, Doku, Gundogan, Simpson-Pusey, Mubama, O'Reilly, McAtee#ManCity | @etihad pic.twitter.com/DjMhE7fP1k 1 hr 30 mins before kickoff: Recent history suggests that this might not be a bad fixture for Manchester City to try and get back on the horse. They have won on each of their past four visits to the King Power Stadium without conceding a goal. However, clean sheets are not really part of the equation for Guardiola's team at this juncture and Leicester have also dished out a couple of the most painful beatings of his tenure. A raucous 4-2 win on this ground eight years ago marked a low point of the Catalan's first season in the Premier League as two late goals from the visitors undeservedly softened the scoreline. Then there was the Foxes' 5-2 victory at a behind-closed-doors Etihad Stadium in September 2021. That defeat immediately preceded the arrival of defensive lynchpin Ruben Dias (currently injured, of course) and City look like they need similarly transformative reinforcements next month. 2 hours before kickoff: It can't go on like this for Manchester City, can it? In the immortal words of Mick McCarthy... it can! Leicester are on a bad run of form themselves but being in a relegation dogfight against an opponent they've often enjoyed cutting down to size could be a combination of circumstances too heady for Pep Guardiola's incredibly brittle team. This Premier League match kicks off in Leicester at 2:30 p.m. local time. Here's how that time translates across some of the major territories: Jamie Vardy sat out the 3-1 loss to Liverpool with a knock. The veteran striker is back and will be keen to add to a handsome career record of nine goals against City. Ricardo Pereira (thigh), Mads Hermansen (groin), Wilfred Ndidi (thigh) and Abdul Fatawu (knee) remain sidelined. Wout Faes is also out with an injury sustained in the loss to Wolves. Jordan Ayew, who scored at Anfield, is suspended for this game, with Facundo Buonanotte coming into the forward line. Leicester lineup (4-2-3-1, right to left): Stolarczyk (GK) — Justin, Coady, Vestergaard, Kristiansen — Winks, Soumare — El Khannouss, Buonanotte, Mavididi — Vardy Injured: Pereira, Hermansen, Ndidi, Fatawu, FaesSuspended: Ayew (yellow-card accumulation) MORE: All the latest Man City news | Premier League schedule for 2024/25 | Latest Premier League top scorer rankings Kyle Walker (illness) and Jack Grealish (muscular) sat out the Everton game and will be assessed alongside fellow absentees Matheus Nunes and Ederson. Defensive injuries have arguably been just as big a problem for City as Rodri being out for the season. John Stones and Ruben Dias remain sidelined, although Nathan Ake was only substituted as a precaution against Everton on his return from a hamstring injury and will probably be asked to go back to the well once more. Savinho and Jeremy Doku started as a dual wing threat last time out, although Guardiola might take a more circumspect approach away from home. Kevin De Bruyne was feeling the effects of a virus on Boxing Day but is likely to return to the starting XI. Man City lineup (4-1-4-1, right to left): Ortega (GK) — Lewis, Akanji, Ake, Gvardiol — Kovacic — Foden, De Bruyne, Silva, Savinho — Haaland Injured: Stones, Dias, Nunes, Ederson, Walker (doubt), Grealish (doubt)Suspended: None Here's how to watch this Premier League match across selected areas of the world's major regions: If you purchase a product or register for an account through one of the links on our site, we may receive compensation. Learn more > Dom is the senior content producer for Sporting News UK. He previously worked as fan brands editor for Manchester City at Reach Plc. Prior to that, he built more than a decade of experience in the sports journalism industry, primarily for the Stats Perform and Press Association news agencies. Dom has covered major football events on location, including the entirety of Euro 2016 and the 2018 World Cup in Paris and St Petersburg respectively, along with numerous high-profile Premier League, Champions League and England international matches. Cricket and boxing are his other major sporting passions and he has covered the likes of Anthony Joshua, Tyson Fury, Wladimir Klitschko, Gennadiy Golovkin and Vasyl Lomachenko live from ringside.

Norovirus.title: About Norovirus | Norovirus | CDC
Norovirus.content: A .gov website belongs to an official government organization in the United States. A lock ( ) or https:// means you've safely connected to the .gov website. Share sensitive information only on official, secure websites. Related Topics: Norovirus is a very contagious virus that causes vomiting and diarrhea. It is sometimes called the "stomach flu" or the "stomach bug." However, norovirus illness is not related to the flu. The flu is caused by the influenza virus. Norovirus causes acute gastroenteritis, an inflammation of the stomach or intestines. Most people with norovirus illness get better within 1 to 3 days; but they can still spread the virus for a few days after. You can get norovirus illness many times in your life because there are many different types of noroviruses. Infection with one type of norovirus may not protect you against other types. It is possible to develop protection against specific types. But it is not known exactly how long protection lasts. This may explain why so many people of all ages get infected during norovirus outbreaks. A person usually develops symptoms 12 to 48 hours after being exposed to norovirus. If you have norovirus illness, you can feel extremely ill, and vomit or have diarrhea many times a day. This can lead to dehydration (loss of body fluids), especially in young children, older adults, and people with other illnesses. Symptoms of dehydration include: Anyone can get infected and sick with norovirus and people of all ages get infected during norovirus outbreaks. Your likelihood of getting a norovirus infection is also determined in part by your genes. If eaten raw, oysters and other filter-feeding shellfish can contain viruses and bacteria that can cause illness or death. Anyone who consumes raw shellfish is at risk of contracting norovirus. Children younger than 5 years old, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are more likely to develop severe infections. Norovirus spreads very easily and quickly in different ways. You can get norovirus by: You can still spread norovirus for 2 weeks or more after you feel better. Norovirus is very contagious, but you can take steps to protect yourself and others, including: Diagnostic methods for norovirus focus on detecting viral RNA (genetic material) or viral antigen. Diagnostic tests are available at all public health laboratories and many clinical laboratories. Most people with norovirus illness get better within 1 to 3 days. There is no specific medicine to treat people with norovirus illness. Antibiotic drugs will not help treat norovirus infections because they fight bacteria, not viruses. Watch for signs of dehydration (loss of body fluids) in children who have norovirus illness. Children who are dehydrated may cry with few or no tears and be unusually sleepy or fussy. If you have norovirus illness, you should drink plenty of liquids to replace fluid lost from vomiting and diarrhea. This will help prevent dehydration. Sports drinks and other drinks without caffeine or alcohol can help with mild dehydration. However, these drinks may not replace important nutrients and minerals. Oral rehydration fluids that you can get over the counter are most helpful for mild dehydration. Dehydration can lead to serious problems. Severe dehydration may require hospitalization for treatment with fluids given through your vein (intravenous or IV fluids). If you think you or someone you are caring for is severely dehydrated, call your doctor. Norovirus is the leading cause of vomiting and diarrhea, and foodborne illness in the United States. Always wash your hands and handle food well. Languages Language Assistance

Norovirus.title: Norovirus infection - Symptoms & causes - Mayo Clinic
Norovirus.content: Norovirus infection can cause severe vomiting and diarrhea that start suddenly. Noroviruses are highly contagious. They commonly spread through food or water that is contaminated during preparation or through contaminated surfaces. Noroviruses can also spread through close contact with a person who has norovirus infection. Diarrhea, stomach pain and vomiting typically begin 12 to 48 hours after exposure. Norovirus infection symptoms usually last 1 to 3 days. Most people recover completely without treatment. However, for some people — especially young children, older adults and people with other medical conditions — vomiting and diarrhea can be severely dehydrating and require medical attention. Norovirus infection occurs most frequently in closed and crowded environments. Examples include hospitals, nursing homes, child care centers, schools and cruise ships. Signs and symptoms of norovirus infection may start suddenly and include: Signs and symptoms usually begin 12 to 48 hours after your first exposure to a norovirus and last 1 to 3 days. You can continue to shed virus in your stool for several weeks after recovery. This shedding can last weeks to months if you have another medical condition. Some people with norovirus infection may show no signs or symptoms. However, they're still contagious and can spread the virus to others. Seek medical attention if you develop diarrhea that doesn't go away within several days. Also call your health care provider if you experience severe vomiting, bloody stools, stomach pain or dehydration. Noroviruses are highly contagious. That means the norovirus infection can easily spread to others. The virus is shed in stool and vomit. You can spread the virus from the time you first have symptoms of illness until several days after you recover. Noroviruses can stay on surfaces and objects for days or weeks. You can get norovirus infection by: Noroviruses are difficult to kill because they can withstand hot and cold temperatures and many disinfectants. Risk factors for becoming infected with a norovirus include: For most people, norovirus infection usually clears up within a few days and isn't life-threatening. But in some people — especially young children; older adults; and people with weakened immune systems or other medical conditions or who are pregnant — norovirus infection can be severe. Norovirus infection can cause severe dehydration and even death. Warning signs of dehydration include: Children who are dehydrated might cry with few or no tears. They might be unusually sleepy or fussy. Norovirus infection is highly contagious. There are many types of noroviruses. Anyone can get norovirus infection more than once. To prevent norovirus infection: To help prevent norovirus infection spread, during illness and for 2 to 3 days after your symptoms end: Mar 04, 2022 CON-XXXXXXXX Mayo Clinic does not endorse companies or products.
